Description: Fragment from a wheel-made pottery sanctuary lamp, either bowl-shaped or ring-shaped, with about forty nozzles and traces of orange slip: traces of five wick-holes remain. Fine orange-red fabric with very fine mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Several similar lamps were found in the Temnos of Aphrodite (Gardner 1888, 48; British Museum GR 1888,0601.151.a-c; 1888,0601.151.d-e; 1888,0601.151.f; 1888,0601.151.g; 1965,0930.884-885). Bailey suggests this and another unregistered Naukratis piece of similar type (GR 1965,0930.882; 1965,0930.883) were also from the Temnos of Aphrodite. For other related types of sanctuary lamp see parallels from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 143), the sanctuary of Hemithea at Kastabos (Cook and Plommer 1966, 55-6, pl. 9) and the sanctuary of Demeter, Knossos (Coldstream 1973, pls 13, 15 and 26), Ephesian types (Bailey 1977, Q 153, Q154) and Rhodian types (ibid, 365, 370). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton. Cook, J. M. and Plommer, W. H. 1966. The Sanctuary of Hemithea at Kastabos, Cambridge. Coldstream, J. N. 1973. Knossos, the Sanctuary of Demeter, London.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q154)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KA.12) (Phase 1)
